message.content: This question requires knowledge about the decomposition process. When a tree is cut down, it eventually rots due to the activities of bacteria, fungi, and other decomposers that break down organic matter. Option (B) is incorrect because stones do not undergo the same decomposition process as organic materials. Option (C) is also incorrect because a living tree is still alive and does not rot. Option (D) is incorrect because sand is an inorganic material and does not undergo the decomposition process.

In this question, we need to determine which item in the list is most likely to rot. Rotting refers to the decomposition or breakdown of organic matter. The most likely item to rot would be a living tree, as it is made of organic matter and would naturally decompose over time. Option (C) is the correct answer. 

Option (A) states that a felled tree rots. This makes sense because once a tree is cut down, it is no longer receiving nutrients and water from its roots, leading to its eventual decay. 

Option (B) states that a stone pile rots. This is incorrect because stone is not organic matter and therefore cannot rot. 

Option (D) states that a pile of sand rots. This is also incorrect because sand is made up of inorganic minerals and does not have the ability to decompose.

This question requires basic knowledge about the process of decomposition. When a tree is felled, it no longer receives nutrients and water from its roots, causing it to eventually decompose or rot. Option (B) is incorrect because a pile of stones does not undergo decomposition like organic matter. Option (C) is also incorrect because a living tree is still receiving nutrients and water, so it is less likely to rot. Option (D) is incorrect because sand is an inorganic material and does not undergo decomposition.

Option (B) is incorrect because rocks or stones do not rot as they are not organic matter. Option (C) is incorrect because a living tree does not rot until it dies. Option (D) is incorrect because sand is an inorganic substance and does not rot.

Option (C) is incorrect because a living tree is still alive and does not rot. Option (D) is incorrect because sand is an inorganic material and does not decompose.

Option (B) is incorrect because stone piles are not organic matter and do not decompose. Option (C) is also incorrect because a living tree is still alive and not undergoing the process of decomposition. Option (D) is incorrect because sand is not organic matter and does not decompose.
